string_table.string: Closed captions. Press the spacebar to toggle captions on and off.
Skip Navigation. Hit enter to return to the slide.

slidelink.displaytext: Machine Learning Applications for the Public Sector
Solving Public Problems with Data (Total Session Length: 25:52)

search.slidetext: machine learning applications for the public sector gideon mann funded by a grant from the www.thegovlab.org
head of data science at bloomberg lp gideon mann 1 identify when machine learning can help you build a new product or service 2 understand the key elements for success in a machine learning project
session outline statistical inquiry statistical inquiry machine learning services supervised machine learning advanced techniques applications considerations

statistical inquiry start with a research question “why is the rate of new businesses going down?” “where should we put a new bus station?” assess data, consider error term the result is an answer: “why did something happen” or “what is the best thing to do”
machine learning services software that makes an algorithmic decision many decisions in the course of a day can’t build using simple rules “programming with data” yes no

supervised machine learning many flavors of machine learning most successful and useful is supervised machine learning observe people making a decision many times, generalize from this decision, and then replicate that decision making
supervised machine learning classification given : a set input predict : 1 from a finite number of possible outcomes
supervised machine learning recommendation given : a person, and a history of actions they’ve taken predict : an action to take from a large and ever-changing set
advanced techniques typically in statistics, deal with cleanly structured data machine learning often deals with data not in a structured form
natural language processing ticket descriptions forms that people have filled in people’s names news stories what kinds of outputs result?

facial recognition e.g., findface : from a picture, find the social media profile of the person (deployed in russia) egor tsvetkov : “it was ridiculously easy to find 60 to 70 percent of the subjects aged between 18 and 35 or so, he found, although for older people it was more difficult.”
image processing clarifai
machine learning workflow data collection and annotation step 1 step 2 step 3 feature engineering and exploration training model deployment model maintenance step 4 step 5

applications quickly becoming ubiquitous enable mass personalization reduce costs of service delivery new capabilities in the next slides, two things to keep in mind: are these classification or recommendation problems? how would you gather supervised training data?

type your answers here google adwords input : user query output : an advertisement is this a classification or recommendation problem? how would you collect training data for this problem? click the glossary button to review definitions of classification and recommendation problems classification classification classification classification classification classification classification recommendation recommendation recommendation recommendation recommendation recommendation recommendation

google adwords this is a recommendation problem, as the set of products available to advertise may change day-to-day. in deployment, training data is provided by google users every time they search for a product and click on an ad. prior to deployment, you might develop a naive heuristic for recommendations.

type your answers here fraud detection credit card charges input : a credit card transaction (amount, location, date and time, recipient) output : fraudulent or not? is this a classification or recommendation problem? how would you collect training data for a machine learning solution? classification classification classification classification classification classification classification recommendation recommendation recommendation recommendation recommendation recommendation recommendation

fraud detection credit card fraud detection is a classification problem; transactions fall into one of two categories (fraudulent/not fraudulent) training data can be generated by recording human evaluations of credit card transactions

type your answers here amazon suggested products input : user with a set of past purchases output : other things user can buy is this a classification or recommendation problem? how would you generate supervised training data? classification classification classification classification classification classification classification recommendation recommendation recommendation recommendation recommendation recommendation recommendation
amazon suggested products this is a recommendation problem training data is generated through observing past shoppers’ buying patterns and/or clicking behavior

type your answers here facebook news feed input : user who has clicked on various posts/articles output : other posts the user might be interested in is this a classification or recommendation problem? how would you come up with training data for this problem? classification classification classification classification classification classification classification recommendation recommendation recommendation recommendation recommendation recommendation recommendation

facebook news feed the news feed is best considered a recommendation problem, as the set of available posts to show the user will change every day the training data is the user’s behavior (which posts they choose to click on) how does this change what people are likely to see in the future?
government applications many government functions are routine, repeatable many easy cases, few hard ones how can you automate and deliver better product?

type your answers here 311 ticket routing input : a ticket describing a problem output : the department it should go to is this a classification or recommendation problem? how would you come up with training data for this problem? classification classification classification classification classification classification classification recommendation recommendation recommendation recommendation recommendation recommendation recommendation

311 ticket routing this is a classification problem, because there is a static set of possible outputs generating training data would involve first having a person manually complete the process, then allowing the algorithm to attempt to process tickets with human confirmation/correction, finally resulting in a fully automated solution (with some exceptions) what happens if you don’t know where the ticket should go?

type your answers here missing smoke detectors input : house characteristics output : how likely is it to be missing a smoke detector is this a classification or recommendation problem? how would you generate training data? classification classification classification classification classification classification classification recommendation recommendation recommendation recommendation recommendation recommendation recommendation
missing smoke detectors another classification problem training data could be generated via sampling by gathering characteristics of a few houses in each district, then extrapolating

type your answers here grease dumping input : clogged storm drain output : which store is dumping grease into the drain is this a classification or recommendation problem? how would you generate training data? classification classification classification classification classification classification classification recommendation recommendation recommendation recommendation recommendation recommendation recommendation

grease dumping this is a recommendation problem, as the set of possible outputs (restaurants) frequently changes supervised training could involve having someone monitor storm drains for dumping activity what would you do with this model?

considerations cost of mistakes? cost of mistakes? measuring your success measuring your success algorithmic bias algorithmic bias privacy considerations privacy considerations every machine learning service will make a mistake at some point consider: how will you observe that a mistake has occurred? what will you do to remediate the mistake? often, the solution involves including a human in the workflow to monitor for errors sometimes, the cost of a mistake or need for accuracy is so high that, even though a process is routine and repeatable, a computer is not the best solution

considerations cost of mistakes? cost of mistakes? measuring your success measuring your success algorithmic bias algorithmic bias privacy considerations privacy considerations after you deploy a machine learning solution, it's critical to measure how well the system is working measurement strategies include: surveys spot-checking measuring overall system use be sure to determine what extrinsic system of measurement you will use before deploying the solution

considerations cost of mistakes? cost of mistakes? measuring your success measuring your success algorithmic bias algorithmic bias privacy considerations privacy considerations algorithms are perceived as unbiased, but that's an oversimplification algorithms are only as accurate as their training data - biased training data will produce biased output similarly, algorithms trained on humans will reflect those humans' biases it's important (and sometimes legally required) to determine how you can test your algorithm to ensure it's unbiased

considerations cost of mistakes? cost of mistakes? measuring your success measuring your success algorithmic bias algorithmic bias privacy considerations privacy considerations how comfortable are you with using a person's private information to make a decision? e.g., taking a picture of the interior of everyone's home may be a great way to confirm whether or not they have a smoke detector, but it's also very invasive will your algorithm reveal private information once it's deployed? e.g., targeted advertising for baby products to a woman who had not informed her family she was pregnant similarly, algorithms can reveal details about a training population to others who use it e.g., recommending a brand of wine popular in a particular neighborhood to a new resident of that neighborhood

conclusion by now, you should be able to identify: 1 when machine learning can help you build a new product or service 2 what are the key elements for success machine learning enables software that can automate routine human cognitive tasks. in order for it to work, you need a plentiful supply of supervised training examples.

terms.term: A machine learning problem where, given a set of inputs, the algorithm predicts one of a finite set of possible outcomes.
A machine learning problem where, given a person and a history of their past action, the algorithm predicts a future action from a large and ever-changing set of possibilities.
